The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  3.2516970  7.3253014  0.4860802  7.2374617  1.3864790  1.9508151
#>  [7]  1.3598815  0.7527997 57.4676678  1.1320869
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 0.7684885 1.6558524 0.6299766 0.6588442 1.1953423 0.5322440 1.4563647
#>  [8] 0.3522078 0.3438548 0.2801797
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 0.91484927 0.09113373 1.06364984 0.21572761 0.34991819 0.27448022
#>  [7] 0.63260233 2.98557227 0.26564745 0.99878478
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.2411370 0.3256781 0.1035656 0.1138514 0.1341853 0.3286839 0.5771233
#>  [8] 3.7326421 0.2754775 0.6213282
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1]  0.15133835 55.15055428  0.58107876  0.30835083  0.73132452  1.25932239
#>  [7]  0.84200066  0.05271754  0.14043910  0.09271022
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
